Situation1: They are asked to take an active role in leading a significant family ceremony to preserve tradition.
Situation2: Pre-dawn traffic is sparse and holding patterns are empty.
Story: The phone buzzed on the console just as the first streaks of dawn crept over the horizon. My mother’s voice, soft but urgent, reminded me that today was the day I was to lead the family’s ancestral ceremony—a role my grandmother had entrusted to me before she passed. “It’s important, darling. You’re the eldest now. Everyone’s counting on you.” I glanced at the radar screen; the airspace was quiet, only a few blips moving steadily, no holding patterns, no emergencies. Still, protocol demanded my full attention, every second. My supervisor’s words echoed in my mind: “Even in the calm, you must be vigilant. One mistake can cost lives.” I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in—my family’s expectations to honor our traditions, and my duty to keep the skies safe. My heart pounded as I stared at the clock, knowing the ceremony would begin soon, and I was supposed to be at its heart. I gripped the headset tighter, torn between the legacy of my family and the responsibility of my profession, unable to see how I could possibly fulfill both.
